questions.text: Which of the following is not included in part I of death certificate
questions.solution:
• Contributory factors are not included in part I of death certificate.
  • Contributory factors like hypertension, diabetes etc are included in 2nd part of death certificate.
  • First part gives information about direct cause of death and antecedent cause.


Reference:Synopsis of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 28th edition Page number 140

questions.text: Which of the following is also called a tear?
questions.solution:
• A laceration is also called a tear.

The following are commonly used names for mechanical injuries:

  • Abrasions - grazes or scratches
  • Contusions - bruises
  • Lacerations - cuts or tears
  • Incised wounds - cuts, slashes or stabs

Reference:Knight's Forensic Pathology 4th edition Page number 134

questions.text: The following pattern of erythema is characteristic of
questions.solution:
• The given image shows superficial fern-like erythema called arborescent or filigree burns or Lichtenberg's flowers resembling branches of a tree which ischaracteristic of lightning stroke injury.

References:The Essentials Of Forensic Medicine And Toxicology 33rd edition Page number 334

choices.text: Imprisonment upto1 year and fine of Rs 5000
Imprisonment upto 3 years and a fine of Rs 10,000
Imprisonment upto 7 years and unlimited fine
Death sentence but it must be confirmed by high court

questions.text: First Class judicial magistrate may pass a maximum sentence of
questions.solution:
• Maximum sentence which Judicial Magistrate of the First class may pass is 3 years and a fine of Rs 10,000.


  • Maximum sentence which a District and Sessions Judge (DSJ) may pass is Death sentence, but it must be confirmed by the High

References:The Essentials Of Forensic Medicine And Toxicology 33rd edition Page number 8

questions.text: Which of the following poison can be found even in skeletonized remains of the body?
questions.solution:
• Arsenic can be found even in skeletonized remains of the body. It delays putrefaction and can be found in bones, hair, and nails for several years.
  • It becomes fixed in the cancellous tissues of the long bones by the conversion of phosphates to arsenates. The elimination of arsenicin this form is much slower and can be detected in the bones for several years after death.
  • Heavy metals such as lead, copper, mercury, including metalloids like arsenic and antimony, may be found in bones for a prolonged period in cases of chronic poisoning. They are also deposited in hair, nails, etc. For these reasons, when heavy metal poisoning is suspected, these specimens are collected in addition to the routine viscera and body fluids.

Reference:Textbook of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology 2nd edition Page number 184

questions.text: Magistrate inquest is conducted in all except
questions.solution:
• Magistrate inquest is conducted by a district magistrate, sub-divisional magistrate, executive magistrates (collector, deputy collector,tahsilda
  • It is conducted in cases of
  • Death under police custody
  • Death due to police firing
  • Death in prison, reformatories, borstal schools
  • Dowry death
  • Death in psychiatric hospital
  • Exhumation
  • Death or disappearance of any person, or rape of a woman who is under the custody of police or any other person authorised by the court.

References: Synopsis of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 28th edition Page number 4

questions.text: Which of the following tests on live birth are based on the changes in the middle ear?
questions.solution:
Wredin's test is based on the changes in the middle ear.

Tests for live birth:

  • Wredin's test - Before birth, the middle ear does not contain air. It only contains gelatinous embryonic connective tissue. With respiration, the eustachian tube opens and the gelatinous substance is replaced by air. For this, the middle ear must be opened underwater by removing tegmen tympani. If an air bubble comes out, the test is said to be positive. This is not at all reliable.
  • Fodere's test - Based on the increase in the weight of the lung due to increased blood flow after birth. The weight of unrespired lung is 30-40g whereas the weight of respired lung is 60-66g.
  • Ploucquet's test - Based on the ratio of the weight of the lung to the weight of the body in unrespired and respired lungs.
    • Unrespired lungs: Weight of lungs: Weight of body = 1:70
    • Respired lungs: Weight of lungs: weight of body = 1:35
  • Breslau's second life test: Air enters the stomach and intestine during respiration in a live-born fetus. So if respiration has taken place, they float in water, otherwise, they sink.

References:The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology 33rd Edition Page number : 439

questions.text: Identify the sex from the given bones
questions.solution: Reference:Review of forensic medicine and toxicology Gautam Biswas page number 66

questions.text: A person is considered to be hypothermic when their temperature falls below:
questions.solution:
• Hypothermia occurs when the body's core temperature drops below 35°C.
  • Mild hypothermia - Core temperature 32 to 35°C (90 to 95°F)
  • Moderate hypothermia - Core temperature 28 to 32°C (82 to 90°F)
  • Severe hypothermia - Core temperature below 28°C (82°F

Reference: Harrison's Principles Of Internal Medicine - 19th Edition Page number 478e-1

questions.text: A woman was drugged with a substance, which was slipped into her coffee without her knowledge by a man at her workplace. The man confessed that he tried to make her notice him by adding a love philter to her coffee. Which of the following would he have used?
questions.solution:
• A love philter is a magical potion that is supposed to make the person who receives the potion love the one who gave it. These are usually aphrodisiacs.

Some aphrodisiacs that are used as love philter are:

Cantharides

Arsenic

Alcohol

Opium

Cocaine

Cannabis

The use of a love philter might lead to accidental poisoning.

References:The Synopsis of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology 28th Edition Page number 278

choices.text: 5-10 years after closure of outer aspect
5-10 years earlier than closure of outer aspect
Earlier in females as compared to males
Less uniformly as compared to outer aspect

questions.text: Closure of the inner aspect of the cranial sutures occurs
questions.solution:
Cranial sutures:

  • Closure of the cranial sutures begins on the inner aspect by 5-10 years earlier than on the outer aspect.
  • Fusion of sutures occurs comparatively early in males.
  • Endocranial sutural closure is more uniform and more complete than ectocranial suture

Accurate estimation of age cannot be done on the basis of sutural closure of skull.

Reference:Textbook of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology: Principles & Practice 5th edition Page number 42

questions.text:
Which of the following are constituents of smokeless gunpowder?
1.Nitrocellulose
2.Potassium nitrate
3. Nitroglycerine
4. Nitroguanidine
5. Sulphur
questions.solution:
• Smokeless gunpowder contains nitroglycerine, nitrocellulose and nitroguanidine.

Various types of gunpowder

Smokeless powder:

  • Nitrocellulose (single base)
  • Nitrocellulose & Nitroglycerine (double base)
  • Nitrocellulose, Nitroglycerine, and Nitroguanidine (triple base)

Smoke producing powders contain Black Powder:

  • Potassium nitrate
  • Charcoal
  • Sulphur

Semi-smokeless powder:

  • Mixture of 80% black and 20% of the smokeless powder

Reference:Gunshot Wounds : Practical Aspects of Firearms, Ballistics, and Forensic Techniques Page number 20

questions.text: A patient has been bitten by a snake and the relatives have brought the snake with them. Which of the following findings will assure you that the snake is non-poisonous?
questions.solution:
• Incomplete belly scales are usually seen in non-poisonous
  • In poisonous snakes, belly scales are large and cover the entire belly.




Reference:Review of forensic medicine and toxicology by Gautam Biswas edition 4 page number 532

questions.text: Fingerprinting (FINDER) involves recording prints of 8 fingers. Which finger pair is excluded?
questions.solution:
• The finger pair excluded by FINDER are little finger.
  • Fingerprint reader is a computerized automatic fingerprint reading system which can record each fingerprint data in half second. Prints of eight fingers are recorded excluding little fingers.
  • The light reflected from a fingerprint can be measured and converted to digital data which is classified codified and stored in the computer.

References:The Essentials Of Forensic Medicine And Toxicology 33rd edition Page number 87

choices.text: Urinary levels of organophosphorus compound metabolites

questions.text: You are suspecting organophosphorus poisoning in a farmer who presented with chronic fatigue and urinary incontinence. What would be the most accurate investigation to assess potential toxicity?
questions.solution:
• RBC cholinesterase enzyme activity is the most accurate indicator to assess potential organophosphorus (OP) toxicity. It is an indicator of synaptic cholinesterase inhibition.
  • However, plasma butyrylcholinesterase is easier to assay and more easily available. Hence, it is more commonly used.
  • Measurement of parent compound in blood and metabolites urine are rarely carried out in a clinical setting.

References:Tintinalli's Emergency Medicine, 8th Edition Page number 1319, 1320

choices.text: A woman who is in intoxicated state
His wife living under decree of separation
Any person other than his wife
A girl below 18 years of age with her consent

questions.text: For a man to be found guilty of statutory rape, he must have had sexual intercourse with?
questions.solution:
• Statutory rape is having a sexual relationship with a girl who is below 18 years of age even with her consent.
  • Sexual intercourse with a woman who is under the influence of sedative drugs like GHB, rohypnol (flunitrazepam) is called date rape.
  • Sexual intercourse with wife living separately, against her consent is marital rape.
  • Voluntary sexual intercourse between a married person and a person who is not their spouse is adultery.

References:Synopsis of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 28th edition Page number 221

questions.text: Activated charcoal is a:
questions.solution:
• Activated charcoal acts as a mechanical antidote.
  • Mechanical antidotes- They neutralize poisons by mechanical action or prevention of their absorption.
  • Activated charcoal- It acts mechanically by adsorbing and retaining organic and mineral poisons within its pores and thus delays the absorption from the stomach.
  • Demulcents- substances that coat the gastric mucous membrane and thus do not permit the poisons to cause any damage, e.g. milk, starch, egg-white, mineral oil, milk of magnesia, aluminum hydroxide gel, etc
  • Bulky food is the mechanical antidote to glass powder, wherein it acts by imprisoning its particles within its meshes.

Chemical antidotes- They neutralize poison by forming harmless or insoluble compounds or by oxidation when it is brought in contact with them.

  • Common salt decomposes silver nitrate, forming the insoluble silver chloride.
  • Potassium permanganate has oxidizing properties. 1:5000 solution is used in opium poisoning.

Chelating agents (metal complexing agents) are used in the treatment of heavy metal poisoning. The metal-agent complex is more water-soluble than the metal itself, resulting in higher renal excretion of the complex.

Reference:The Essentials Of Forensic Medicine And Toxicology, 33rd edition Page number 516

questions.text: A patient was brought in with a history of consumption of acid. His last meal was one hour ago. What pattern of gastric mucosal injury would you expect to see in this patient?
questions.solution:
• The area marked in image 2 depicts the most likely pattern of gastric mucosal injury in this patient.
  • The pathway that fluids (acid, alkali, water) take in a food-filled stomach is known as magenstrasse. It is present along the lesser curvature of the stomach. This is where the greatest damage to gastric mucosa takes place, in corrosive injury.
  • In an empty stomach, the maximum injury occurs to the lower half to two-thirds of the body, with sparing of the fundus (image 3).

References:Synopsis of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 28th edition Page number 283

questions.text: A person was walking home from his work when suddenly a robber attacked him. They both started fighting and the robber held him from behind as shown in the image. During this, the victim lost his life due to difficulty in breathing. What is this type of strangulation known as?
questions.solution:
• The type of strangulation shown in the given image is mugging.
  • The term strictly means throttling by pressure from an arm held around the throat. The attack is usually made from behind, the neck being trapped in the crook of the elbow. Pressure is then exerted either on the front of the larynx or at one or both sides by the forearm and upper arm.

Other options

A)Garrotting



to kill someone by putting a metal wire or collar around their neck and pulling it

B)Bansdola



This is a form of strangulation practiced in Northern India.In this the neck is compressed between two sticks or hard objects,usually bamboos(Knowns bans),one being placed actross the throat in front and another behind.


D)Burking



Burking is a combination of smothering and traumatic asphyxia.

Reference:Knight's Forensic Pathology 4th edition Page number 386

questions.text: An old man who was lying on the roadside is brought to the causalty by the police. On detailed history, he reveals that he has had no food for the past few weeks. On examination, he is severely emaciated. What is the likely finding in the gall bladder?
questions.solution:
• The given clinical scenario points to starvation. In this condition, the gall bladder is distended.
  • In starvation, bile does not get secreted into the duodenum due to the absence of food entering the stomach and intestine. Hence, bile gets accumulated in the gall bladder which gets distended.
  • The feeling of intense hunger lasts for 30-48 hours. A person can survive for 10-12 days without food and water and for 6-8 weeks without food alone.
  • Loss of 40% of body weight is usually fatal. Loss of 70-90% of body fat and 20% of body protein is fatal. There is a reduction in the weight and size of all organs except the brain.

References:Knight's Forensic Pathology 4th edition Page number 417

questions.text: According to the Indian Evidence Act, section 45 gives information regarding:
questions.solution:
• IEA Section 45 gives information regarding Expert witnesses.
  • The important Sections under IEA (Indian evidence act) include:


Reference:The Essentials Of Forensic Medicine And Toxicology, 33rd edition Page numbers 12

questions.text: The following image shows:
questions.solution:
• The above image is of a joule burn. It is formed at the point of contact with electricity. It is more popularly referred to as 'electricalburns' or 'electrical Marks.'
  • Electrical burns may not always be evident, even in cases of fatal electrocutions as it is dependent on a number of factors like contact area, duration, presence of intervening moisture etc.

Soot-soiling occurs from the person holding a shotgun barrel.

  • In tight flesh contact wounds, soot soiling and muzzle marks are uncommon. If there is loose contact or clothes are interposed, there may be soiling or muzzle marks.
  • In a case involving a close-range shotgun injury, if a victim catches the barrel of the gun, there may be soot-soling of the hands.

Frost Bite:



Above is the image of frostbite. It occurs when the body is exposed to cold temperatures.

Scalding:



Scalds are due to exposure to wet heat like hot water or steam.

Reference:Knight's Forensic Pathology 4th edition Page number 246

questions.text: Which of the following is the most reliable criterion for age determination from Gustafson's method?
questions.solution:
• Transparency of the root is the most reliable criterion in Gustafson's method.
  • Gustafson's method of estimation of age of an individual is based on physiological changes in teeth. It is mainly useful in adults over 25 years of age.
  • Gustafson's criteria includes:
    • Attrition - wear and tear changes of occlusal surface
    • Periodontosis - regression of gums surrounding the tooth resulting in loosening of the tooth and falling
    • Secondary dentin - deposition of dentin in pulp cavity
    • Cementum apposition - deposition of cementum in the root forming incremental lines
    • Root resorption - involves both cementum and dentin
    • Transparency of the root - This is the most reliable criteria. Canals in dentin get filled with mineral and they become less transparent.

References:Synopsis of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 28th edition Page number 43

questions.text: In which of the following cases is glove and stocking hypostasis most likely to be seen?
questions.solution:
• Glove and stocking hypostasis indicates postmortem staining of legs, feet, hands, and forearm. This occurs in the vertical suspension of the body as in hanging where these parts form the dependant parts.

Sites of postmortem hypostasis depending on the position of the body:


Reference:Synopsis of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 28th edition Page number 89

questions.text: The second most common mode of death in fatal child abuse around the world is:
questions.solution:
• The second most common mode of death in fatal child abuse around the world is rupture of an abdominal viscus.
  • The most common mode of death in fatal child abuse is head trauma.

Reference:Knight's Forensic Pathology 4th edition Page number. 476

questions.text: What percent of the stature of an individual is contributed by the length of the vertebral column?
questions.solution:
• The length of the vertebral column is 35% of the stature of an individual

Reference: knights forensic pathology 4 th edition, page number 450

questions.text: Police were investigating a serial killer who hangs his victims upside down which eventually led to their death.What is the most likely cause of death in these victims?
questions.solution:
• In an inverted crucifixion, death occurs due to postural asphyxia.
  • In the case of inverted crucifixion, asphyxia occurs as a result of the impedance of inspiration by the weight of the abdominal viscera upon the diaphragm


Reference:Knight's Forensic Pathology 4th edition Page number 367

questions.text: Charas is
questions.solution:
• Resin exuding from the leaves and stems of the Cannabis indica plant is known as Charas.

Charas:

  • It is also called as Hashish.
  • It is the purest form of cannabis obtained from resin of Cannabis indica.
  • It is the resin (dope or shit) exuding from the leaves and stems of the plant.
  • It is dark green or brown in color, and contains 25 to 40 per cent of the active principle.
  • This is also mixed with tobacco and used to smoke by a pipe or hookah.

Cannabis poisoning:

  • Cannabis is classified under deliriant cerebral neurotic plant poison.
  • Active principle is usually a fat soluble oleoresin called cannabinol.

Cannabis preparations are:

  • Ganja
  • Charas
  • Bhang
  • Marijuana

Reference:Synopsis of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 28th edition Page number: 346

questions.text: Black postmortem lividity is seen in
questions.solution: Reference:Textbook of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology 2nd edition Page number 146

questions.text: What is the most common cause of mortality in patients with organophosphate poisoning?
questions.solution:
• The most common cause of death in organophosphate poisoning is respiratory failure. It usually occurs within 24 hours in untreatedpatients, secondary to paralysis of respiratory muscles.

Reference:Tintinalli's Emergency Medicine, 8th Edition Page number 1321

questions.text: What is the retrograde propulsion of tissue from the entry wound towards the firearm known as?
questions.solution:
• The retrograde propulsion of tissue from the entry wound towards the firearm is known as backspatter.
  • Gunshot contact wounds and close-range discharges may cause blood and tissue fragments to enter the muzzle, It is due to negative pressure created following the discharge. This is known as backspatter.
  • Sometimes blood and tissue may soil the hand or arm of the person firing the gun, a matter of considerable significance in forensic science,
  • Option A: Blowback phenomenon: This is seen at the entry wound in a contact shot against a bone, where the gases rebound against the bone and exit through the entry wound, creating a stellate shaped margin at the entry wound.
  • Option B & C: Retrodispersion and backward scatter are not effects seen in firearm injuries.

References:Knight's Forensic Pathology 4th edition Page number 256

questions.text: From which part of the plant shown below is the toxic principle derived?
questions.solution:
• The plant shown in the image is Papaver somniferum. The toxic part of the plant is the unripe fruit capsule from which the toxic principle is derived.

References:Textbook of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology Page number 494

questions.text: Exception to the rule of professional secrecy is allowed under the following circumstances except
questions.solution:
• Interest of relatives is not an exception for Professional secrecy.

Exceptions to the rule of Professional secrecy includes :

No CIVIC SINS

  • No - Notifiable diseases, birth, death
  • C- suspected Crime
  • I - self Interest
  • V- Venereal disease (STD)
  • C- Court of law
  • S- Social duty
  • I- Infectious disease
  • N- Negligence suits
  • S- Servant and employee

References:Textbook of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology: Principles & Practice 5th edition Page number 349

questions.text: You notice tearing of the skin at the ends of a laceration on a victim. What is this finding known as?
questions.solution:
• Tearing at the ends of a laceration are called swallow-tails. These are seen at angles diverging from the main laceration itself.

It is shown in the image below



  • Option A: Sparrow's foot marks are seen in windshield injuries in car accidents.
  • Option B: Wedge-shaped injuries are seen in stabbing with a single-edged weapon.
  • Option C: Fish-tails: These may be seen in stab wounds where the skin splits at the corner.

The image below shows fish-tail in a stab wound.



References:Textbook of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology: Principles & Practice 5th edition Page number 221

choices.text: Death of mother due to miscarriage
Preventing the child being born alive

questions.text: What does IPC Section 314 deal with?
questions.solution:
• IPC Section 314 deals with the death of the mother due to miscarriage.

Important sections of IPC relating to miscarriages:



Reference:Textbook of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology: Principles & Practice, 5th edition Page number 387

questions.text: An unmarried mother purposefully drowned her newborn infant in the bathtub, She will be punished under which of the following?
questions.solution:
• Infanticide is considered murder and hence punishment is given under section 302 IPC.

Other relevant sections include:

  • Section 315 and 316 - offence of feticide and infanticide
  • Section 317 PC - Abandoning the child of <12 years
  • Section 318 IPC - Concealment of birth
  • Option A: IPC 102 deals with commencement and continuance of the private defence of the body.
  • Option C: IPC 304 deals with punishment for culpable homicide not amounting to murder.
  • Option D: IPC 306 deals with punishment for abetment to suicide.

References:The Synopsis Of Forensic Medicine And Toxicology Page number 154

questions.text: The ouch-ouch disease is due to the toxicity of which of the following?
questions.solution:
• Itai-Itai disease (Japan), also called ouch-ouch disease is due to bone pain caused by cadmium.
  • Cadmium causes nephrotoxicity leading to hypercalciuria. This subsequently causes osteomalacia leading to bone pain.

Reference:Tintinalli's Emergency Medicine, 8th Ed Page number 1335

questions.text: A man presents with multiple bruises over his left arm. He puts allegations that his neighbor assaulted him. are suspecting malingering. Which of the following may have been used to simulate these bruises?
questions.solution:
• Semecarpus anacardium can be used to produce fake bruises.
  • When the juice of the seed is applied to the skin, it causes irritation, itching, and a painful blister. The lesion resembles a bruise.
  • The image shows Semecarpus anacardium seeds which are black, cone, or heart-shaped with a rough projection at the base.


References:Review Of Forensic Medicine And toxicology Including Clinical And Pathological Aspects Page number 520

questions.text: Which of the following is not involved in the Marshall's triad for blast injuries?
questions.solution:
• Fracture is not included in the Marshall's triad for blast injuries.

Marshall's triad is associated with blast injuries. The triad includes:

  • Bruises
  • Abrasions
  • Puncture lacerations

Reference:The Essentials Of Forensic Medicine And Toxicology, 33rd edition Page numbers 239

questions.text: The term 'Monday morning fever' is generally used for the symptoms associated with poisoning by which of the following agents?
questions.solution:
• The term Monday morning fever is generally used for the symptoms associated with Zinc poisoning.

Monday morning fever(Also called Smelter shakes/Brass chills/Metal fume fever) was described as early as 1669 in brass foundry workers as 'brass foundryman's ague.

  • Symptoms of metal fume fever occur up to 24 hour after exposure to zinc oxide fumes. It presents as an influenza-like illness with headache, fever, sweating, chest tightness and discomfort, and joint pains.Typically, symptoms appear after the weekend, thereby giving rise to the term 'Monday morning fever.
  • The illness usually has good prognosis, and the symptoms often improve towards the end of the working week as some short-term immunity from previous symptoms usually develops.
  • It has been shown that inhalation of zinc oxide fumes is associated with a dose-dependent marked inflammatory response in the lung even if clinical symptoms do not occur.
  • The pathogenesis is not known, but is thought to result from endogenous pyrogen release due to cell lysis.
  • Other metals that produce this condition may include copper, magnesium, iron, chromium, cadmium, nickel, manganese, mercury, cobalt, lead antimony, silver and aluminium, etc.
  • Exposure to zinc chloride ammunition bombs (hexite) has led to the development of fatal adult respiratory distress syndrome
  • Zinc toxicity resembles malarial chills.

Reference:Textbook of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology: Principles & Practice 5 th edition Page number 1566

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the legal term corpus delicti?
questions.solution:
• Corpus delicti, also known as the body of offense, says that a crime must be proved to have occurred before a person can be convicted of committing that crime.
  • The main part of corpus delicti is the establishment of the identity of the dead body and infliction of violence in a particular way, at a particular time and place, by the person or persons charged with a crime and none other.
  • A conviction for an offense does not necessarily depend upon the corpus delicti if there are eyewitnesses or strong corroborativeevidence.

In a charge of homicide, it includes:

  • Positive identification of the dead body (victim)
  • Proof of its death by a criminal act of the accused

Reference:Textbook of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology: Principles & Practice 5th edition Page number 35

questions.text: The 'hold-on effect' is characteristically seen in
questions.solution:
• The hold-on effect is seen in electrical injuries.
  • When the entry point is in the hand, the stronger flexor muscles of the arm go into spasm and cause a hold-on effect. Any object being held in the hand is involuntarily clenched and the current thus continues to flow.

Reference:Knight's Forensic Pathology 4th edition Page number 328

choices.text: Frontal and maxillary sinuses are larger
Frontal and parietal eminences are larger

questions.text: Which of the following trait is a feature of the female skull?
questions.solution:
Differentiating features between male and female skull:


Reference:Review of forensic medicine and toxicology Gautam Biswas edition 3 page number 64

questions.text: The injury is shown in the image results from?
questions.solution:
• Injury shown in the image is suggestive of a scald burn which occurs due to the application of moist heat commonly involving only superficial layers of the skin.

Moist heat includes

  • Hot water or oil or any liquid at or near boiling point
  • Superheated industrial steam.

Degree of Scalding:

  • Erythema
  • Vesication
  • Necrosis of dermis


Reference:Textbook of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology 2nd edition Page number 311

questions.text: Voyeurism is punished under
questions.solution:
• Voyeurism is punishable under section 354C IPC with imprisonment of not less than 1 year, which may extend upto 3 years. For the second and subsequent offenses imprisonment of 3-7 years is given.

Section 354 IP- Lays down punishment for indecent assault

  • 354A - Sexual harassment.
  • 354B - Disrobing a female
  • 354C - Voyeurism
  • 354D - Stalking

References:Synopsis of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 28th edition Page number 221

questions.text: A person walks into the ER with lacerations on his face which looks like sparrow footmarks. What might be most likely cause of this injury?
questions.solution:
• The likely cause of injury in the given scenario is shattered windshield glass injury.
  • In a road traffic accident, the shattered windshield glass produces multiple lacerations, usually on the face. These lacerations resemblesparrow footmarks due to contact with the shattered windscreen glass.

Reference:Knight's Forensic Pathology 4th edition Page number 280

questions.text: The autopsy done in a case of poisoning reveals the leather bottle appearance of the stomach. Which of the following is the likely poison ingested by the patient?
questions.solution:
• The autopsy finding of leather bottle appearance of gastric mucosa is characteristic of carbolic acid (phenol) poisoning.
  • Leather bottle appearance refers to the hardening of the gastric wall. Therefore, gastric lavage can be done in phenol poisoning unlike other corrosives where gastric lavage is contraindicated.

References:Textbook of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology 2nd edition Page number 453

questions.text: What does the Sin of Gomorrah refer to?
questions.solution:
• Buccal coitus is also known as the sin of Gomorrah Coitus Per Os. The male genital organ is introduced into the mouth of another male or female
  • Teeth marks or abrasions on the penis, semen in the respiratory tract/stomach could be the clues to diagnosis. Buccal swabs are useful for only up to 9 hours. Buccal coitus can lead to death by aspiration of semen or impaction of the penis in the hypopharynx.
  • Option A: Sodomy is anal intercourse between 2 males or between a male and a female.
  • Option C: Incest is sexual intercourse between man and woman who are related by blood or a certain degree of blood relationship.
  • Option D: Bestiality is the sexual intercourse of a human being with a lower animal.

References:Synopsis of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology, 28th edition Page number 230

choices.text: Can pass death sentence but has to be confirmed by the High Court
Can pass a sentence of imprisonment for 10 years only
Can pass a sentence of imprisonment for 7 years only

questions.text: Which of the the following is a limitation for sessions court?
questions.solution:
• Sessions court can pass a death sentence but has to be confirmed by the high court.
  • It is the highest judicial tribunal for district and is located in the district head quarters. The court is presided over by the Sessions Judge, appointed by the High Court. High Court may also appoint Additional Sessions Judges and Assistant Sessions Judges to exercise jurisdiction in the court of sessions.
  • It takes up only the cases of criminal offenses referred by Magistrate's courts.
  • Magistrate's courts are criminal courts presided over by the Judicial/ Metropolitan Magistrates. In every district the State Governmentafter consultation with High Court may establish as many Courts of Judicial Magistrate as it may consider necessary.
  • Judicial judges can pass a sentence of imprisonment for 7 years only and cannot pass a death sentence.

Reference:Textbook of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology 2nd edition Page number 8

questions.text: A pregnant lady was awarded death sentence. However her hanging can be postponed by the High court. This comes under which section of Cr PC
questions.solution:
• Cr PC 416deals with Postponement of capital punishment of pregnant women.


Reference:The Essentials Of Forensic Medicine And Toxicology 33rd edition Page number 392
